revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{Globalize/US|date=November 2010}} {{Refimprove|date=July 2008}} }}
In [[proprietary software]], an '''end-user license agreement''' ('''EULA''') or '''software license agreement''' is the [[contract]] between the licensor and purchaser, establishing the purchaser's right to use the software. The license may define ways under which the copy can be used, in addition to the automatic rights of the buyer including the first sale doctrine and {{USC|17|117}} (freedom to use, archive, re-sale, and backup with legal restrictions).
Many form contracts are only contained in digital form, and only presented to a user as a [[#Shrink-wrap and click-wrap licenses|click-through]] where the user must "accept". As the user may not see the agreement until after he or she has already purchased the software, these documents may be [[contracts of adhesion]].
Software companies often make special agreements with large businesses and government entities that include support contracts and specially drafted warranties.
Some end-user license agreements accompany shrink-wrapped software that is presented to a user sometimes on paper or more usually electronically, during the installation procedure. The user has the choice of accepting or rejecting the agreement. The installation of the software is conditional to the user clicking a button labelled "accept". See <!--the # (called an "anchor") means it is on the same page-->[[#Shrink-wrap and click-wrap licenses|below]].
Many EULAs assert extensive liability limitations. Most commonly, an EULA will attempt to [[hold harmless]] the software licensor in the event that the software causes damage to the user's computer or data, but some software also proposes limitations on whether the licensor can be held liable for damage that arises through improper use of the software (for example, incorrectly using tax preparation software and incurring penalties as a result). One case upholding such limitations on [[consequential damages]] is ''M.A. Mortenson Co. v. Timberline Software Corp., et al.''{{citation needed|date=November 2017}} Some EULAs also claim restrictions on venue and applicable law in the event that a legal dispute arises.
Some copyright owners use EULAs in an effort to circumvent limitations the applicable copyright law places on their copyrights (such as the limitations in sections 107–122 of the [[United States Copyright Act]]), or to expand the scope of control over the work into areas for which copyright protection is denied by law (such as attempting to charge for, regulate or prevent private performances of a work beyond a certain number of performances or beyond a certain period of time). Such EULAs are, in essence, efforts to gain control, by contract, over matters upon which copyright law precludes control. <ref name=moglen>{{cite web |title=Enforcing the GNU GPL |url=https://www.gnu.org/philosophy/enforcing-gpl.html |work=gnu.org |publisher=[[Free Software Foundation]], Inc. |accessdate=20 May 2013 |author=Eben Moglen |authorlink=Eben Moglen |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130426151337/http://www.gnu.org/philosophy/enforcing-gpl.html |archivedate=26 April 2013 |date=10 September 2001 }}</ref> This kind of EULAs concurs in aim with [[Digital rights management|DRM]] and both may be used as alternate methods for widening control over software.
In disputes of this nature in the United States, cases are often appealed and different circuit courts of appeal sometimes disagree about these clauses. This provides an opportunity for the [[U.S. Supreme Court]] to intervene, which it has usually done in a scope-limited and cautious manner, providing little in the way of [[precedent]] or settled law. {{Citation needed|date=May 2017}}
End-user license agreements are usually lengthy, and written in highly specific legal language, making it difficult for the average user to give informed consent<ref>Bashir, M., Hayes, C., Lambert, A. D., & Kesan, J. P. (2015). Online privacy and informed consent: The dilemma of information asymmetry. Proceedings of the Association for Information Science and Technology, 52(1), 1-10. doi:10.1002/pra2.2015.145052010043</ref>. If the company designs the end-user license agreement in a way that intentionally discourages users to read them, and uses difficult to understand language, many users may be unable to give their informed consent. This is especially relevant when these agreements concern the privacy of the users. However, users are ultimately responsible for reading signing and understanding these agreements.
==Comparison with free software licenses== {{main|Free software license}} A [[free software]] license grants users of that software the rights to use for any purpose, modify and redistribute creative works and software, both of which are forbidden by the defaults of copyright, and generally not granted with [[proprietary software]]. These licenses typically include a disclaimer of [[warranty]], but this feature is not unique to free software. <ref>{{cite journal |title=A Comparison of the GPL and the Microsoft EULA |date=5 May 2003 |pages=3, 12–16 |url=http://asyd.net/docs/misc/comparing_the_gpl_to_eula.pdf |accessdate=19 July 2013 |author=Con Zymaris |format=PDF |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081006164013/http://www.asyd.net/docs/misc/comparing_the_gpl_to_eula.pdf |archivedate=6 October 2008 }}</ref> [[Copyleft]] licenses also include a key addition provision that must be followed in order to copy or modify the software, that requires the user to provide source code for the work and to distribute their modifications under the same license (or sometimes a compatible one); thus effectively protecting derivative works from losing the original permissions and being used in proprietary programs.
Unlike EULAs, free software licenses do not work as contractual extensions to existing legislation. No agreement between parties is ever held, because a copyright license is simply a declaration of permissions on something that otherwise would be disallowed by default under copyright law.<ref name=moglen />
==Shrink-wrap and click-wrap licenses {{Anchor|Shrink-wrap and click-wrap licenses}}== {{main|Clickwrap|Browsewrap|Shrink wrap contract}}
The term '''shrink-wrap license''' refers colloquially to any software license agreement which is enclosed within a software package and is inaccessible to the customer until after purchase. Typically, the license agreement is printed on paper included inside the boxed software. It may also be presented to the user on-screen during installation, in which case the license is sometimes referred to as a '''click-wrap license'''. The inability of the customer to review the license agreement before purchasing the software has caused such licenses to run afoul of legal challenges in some cases.
Whether shrink-wrap licenses are legally binding differs between jurisdictions, though a majority of jurisdictions hold such licenses to be enforceable. At particular issue is the difference in opinion between two US courts in ''[http://www.internetlibrary.com/cases/lib_case209.cfm Klocek v. Gateway]'' and ''[http://www.netlitigation.com/netlitigation/cases/brower.htm Brower v. Gateway]''. Both cases involved a shrink-wrapped license document provided by the online vendor of a computer system. The terms of the shrink-wrapped license were not provided at the time of purchase, but were rather included with the shipped product as a printed document. The license required the customer to return the product within a limited time frame if the license was not agreed to. In ''Brower'', New York's state appeals court ruled that the terms of the shrink-wrapped license document were enforceable because the customer's assent was evident by its failure to return the merchandise within the 30 days specified by the document. The U.S. District Court of Kansas in ''Klocek'' ruled that the contract of sale was complete at the time of the transaction, and the additional shipped terms contained in a document similar to that in ''Brower'' did not constitute a contract, because the customer never agreed to them when the contract of sale was completed.
Further, in ''[[ProCD v. Zeidenberg]]'', the license was ruled enforceable because it was necessary for the customer to assent to the terms of the agreement by clicking on an "I Agree" button in order to install the software. In [[Specht v. Netscape Communications Corp.]], however, the licensee was able to download and install the software without first being required to review and positively assent to the terms of the agreement, and so the license was held to be unenforceable.
Click-wrap license agreements refer to website based contract formation (see [[iLan Systems, Inc. v. Netscout Service Level Corp.]]). A common example of this occurs where a user must affirmatively assent to license terms of a website, by ''clicking'' "yes" on a pop-up, in order to access website features. This is therefore analogous to shrink-wrap licenses, where a buyer implied agrees to license terms by first removing the software package's shrink-wrap and then utilizing the software itself. In both types of analysis, focus is on the actions of end user and asks whether there is an explicit or implicit acceptance of the additional licensing terms.
==Product liability== Most licenses for software sold at retail disclaim (as far as local laws permit) any [[warranty]] on the performance of the software and limit liability for any damages to the purchase price of the software. One well-known case which upheld such a disclaimer is Mortenson v. Timberline .
==Patent== {{main|Software patent}} In addition to the implied [[exhaustion doctrine]], the distributor may include patent licenses along with software.
==Reverse engineering== Forms often prohibit users from [[reverse engineering]]. This may also serve to make it difficult to develop third-party software which interoperates with the licensed software, thus [[Vendor lock-in|increasing the value of the publisher's solutions]] through decreased customer choice. In the United States, EULA provisions can preempt the reverse engineering rights implied by fair use, c.f. [[Bowers v. Baystate Technologies]].
Some licenses<ref>Examples include [http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms994405.aspx Microsoft .NET Framework redistributable EULA]</ref> purport to prohibit a user's right to release data on the performance of the software, but this has yet to be challenged in court.
==Enforceability of EULAs in the United States== {{Primary sources|section about the legal enforceability of end-user license agreements|date=July 2015}}
The enforceability of an EULA depends on several factors, one of them being the court in which the case is heard. Some courts that have addressed the validity of the shrinkwrap license agreements have found some EULAs to be invalid, characterizing them as [[adhesion contract|contracts of adhesion]], [[Unconscionability|unconscionable]], and/or unacceptable pursuant to the [[Uniform Commercial Code|U.C.C.]]—see, for instance, ''[[Step-Saver Data Systems, Inc. v. Wyse Technology]]'',<ref>939 F.2d 91 (3rd Cir., 1991)</ref> ''[[Vault Corp. v. Quaid Software Ltd.]]''.<ref>847 F.2d 255 (5th Cir., 1988)</ref> Other courts have determined that the shrinkwrap license agreement is valid and enforceable: see ''[[ProCD, Inc. v. Zeidenberg]]'',<ref>86 F.3d 1447 (7th Cir., 1996)</ref> ''[[Microsoft Corp. v. Harmony Comps. & Elecs., Inc.|Microsoft v. Harmony Computers]]'',<ref>846 F. Supp. 208 (E.D.N.Y., 1994)</ref> ''[[Novell v. Network Trade Center]]'',<ref>25 F.Supp.2d 1218 (D. Utah, 1997)</ref> and ''[[Ariz. Cartridge Remanufacturers Ass'n v. Lexmark Int'l, Inc.]]''<ref>421 F.3d 981 (9th Cir., 2005)</ref> may have some bearing as well. No court has ruled on the validity of EULAs generally; decisions are limited to particular provisions and terms.
The [[United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit|7th Circuit]] and [[United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit|8th Circuit]] subscribe to the "licensed and not sold" argument, while most other circuits do not {{Citation needed|date=September 2007}}. In addition, the contracts' enforceability depends on whether the state has passed the [[Uniform Computer Information Transactions Act]] (UCITA) or [[Anti-UCITA]] ([[UCITA Bomb Shelter]]) laws. In Anti-UCITA states, the [[Uniform Commercial Code]] (UCC) has been amended to either specifically define software as a good (thus making it fall under the UCC), or to disallow contracts which specify that the terms of contract are subject to the laws of a state that has passed UCITA.
Recently{{when|date=December 2013}}, publishers have begun to [[encryption|encrypt]] their software packages to make it impossible for a user to install the software without either agreeing to the license agreement or violating the [[Digital Millennium Copyright Act]] (DMCA) and [[WIPO Copyright Treaty|foreign counterparts]].{{citation needed|date=December 2013}}
The DMCA specifically provides for reverse engineering of software for interoperability purposes, so there was some controversy as to whether software license agreement clauses which restrict this are enforceable. The [[United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit|8th Circuit]] case of ''[[Davidson & Associates v. Jung]]''<ref>422 F. 3d 630 (8th Cir., 2005)</ref> determined that such clauses are enforceable, following the [[Federal Circuit]] decision of ''[[Bowers v. Baystate Technologies|Baystate v. Bowers]]''.<ref>302 F.3d 1334 (Fed. Cir., 2002)</ref>
==Criticism== [[Jerry Pournelle]] wrote in 1983, "I've seen no evidence to show that ... Levitical agreements — full of "Thou Shalt Nots" — have any effect on piracy". He gave an example of an EULA that was impossible for a user to comply with, stating "Come on, fellows. No one expects these agreements to be kept". Noting that in practice many companies were more generous to their customers than their EULAs required, Pournelle wondered "Why, then, do they insist on making their customers sign 'agreements' that the customer has no intention of keeping, and which the company ''knows'' won't be kept? ... Must we continue making hypocrites out of both publishers and customers?"<ref name="pournelle198306">{{cite magazine | url=https://archive.org/stream/byte-magazine-1983-06/1983_06_BYTE_08-06_16-Bit_Designs#page/n411/mode/2up | title=Zenith Z-100, Epson QX-10, Software Licensing, and the Software Piracy Problem | magazine=BYTE | date=June 1983 | accessdate=20 October 2013 | author=Pournelle, Jerry | pages=411}}</ref>
One common criticism of end-user license agreements is that they are often far too lengthy for users to devote the time to thoroughly read them. In March 2012, the [[PayPal]] end-user license agreement was 36,275 words long<ref>{{cite web|title=No One Reads the "Terms And Conditions" and Here’s Why|url=http://1025kiss.com/no-one-reads-the-terms-and-conditions-and-heres-why/|publisher=102.5 KISSFM|accessdate=24 November 2012|author=Heathen|date=23 March 2012}}</ref> and in May 2011 the [[iTunes]] agreement was 56 pages long.<ref>{{cite news|last=Pidaparthy|first=Umika|title=What you should know about iTunes' 56-page legal terms|url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/TECH/web/05/06/itunes.terms/|accessdate=24 November 2012|newspaper=CNN|date=May 6, 2011}}</ref> News sources reporting these findings asserted that the vast majority of users do not read the documents because of their length.
Several companies have parodied this belief that users do not read the end-user-license agreements by adding unusual clauses, knowing that few users will ever read them. As an [[April Fool's Day]] joke, [[Gamestation]] added a clause stating that users who placed an order on April 1, 2010 agreed to irrevocably [[Deal with the Devil|give their soul]] to the company, which 7,500 users agreed to. Although there was a checkbox to exempt out of the "immortal soul" clause, few users checked it and thus Gamestation concluded that 88% of their users did not read the agreement.<ref>{{cite news|title=7,500 Online Shoppers Unknowingly Sold Their Souls|url=http://www.foxnews.com/tech/2010/04/15/online-shoppers-unknowingly-sold-souls/|accessdate=24 November 2012|newspaper=FoxNews.com|date=April 15, 2010}}</ref> The program [[PC Pitstop]] included a clause in their end-user license agreement stating that anybody who read the clause and contacted the company would receive a monetary reward, but it took four months and over 3,000 software downloads before anybody collected it.<ref>{{cite web|last=Magid|first=Larry|title=PC Pitstop|url=http://www.pcpitstop.com/spycheck/eula.asp|accessdate=24 November 2012}}</ref> During the installation of version 4 of the Advanced Query Tool the installer measured the elapsed time between the appearance and the acceptance of the end-user license agreements to calculate the average reading speed. If the agreements were accepted fast enough a dialog window “congratulated” the users to their absurdly high reading speed of several hundred words per second.<ref>{{cite web|last=Willmott|first=Don|title=Backspace (v22n08)|url=https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,1034132,00.asp|work=PCMag.com|accessdate=8 June 2013}}</ref> ''[[South Park]]'' parodied this in the episode "[[HumancentiPad]]", where [[Kyle Broflovski|Kyle]] had neglected to read the terms of service for his last iTunes update and therefore inadvertently agreed to have [[Apple Inc.|Apple]] employees experiment upon him.<ref>{{cite web|last=O'Grady|first=Jason D.|title=South Park parodies iTunes terms and conditions|url=http://www.zdnet.com/blog/apple/south-park-parodies-itunes-terms-and-conditions/10043|publisher=ZDNet|accessdate=24 November 2012}}</ref>
End-user license agreements have also been criticized for containing terms that impose onerous obligations on consumers. For example, Clickwrapped, a service that rates consumer companies according to how well they respect the rights of users, reports that they increasingly include a term that prevents a user from suing the company in court.<ref>Jamillah Knowles. ''Clickwrapped report tells you which sites claim ownership of your content, and you’ll be surprised''. TheNextWeb. August 21, 2012. Accessed July 29, 2013.</ref>
==See also== * [[Abandonware]] * [[Clickwrap|Clickwrap license]] * [[Free software license]] * [[:wikt:Appendix:Glossary of legal terms in technology|Glossary of legal terms in technology]] ** [[Good faith (law)]] **[[Contra proferentem]] * [[Index of Articles Relating to Terms of Service and Privacy Policies]] * [[License manager]] * [[List of software licenses]] * [[Shrink wrap contract]] * [[Software Asset Management]] * [[Software license]] * [[Terms of service]] * ''[[Vernor v. Autodesk, Inc.]]''
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.frictionlessinsight.com/archives/2002/03/you-may-read-th.html Accessible editorial on enforcability of various EULA-type licenses in the United States from 2002..]
{{DEFAULTSORT:End-user license agreement}} [[Category:Terms of service]] [[Category:Software licenses]] [[Category:Contract law]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2015}} {{Use British English|date=June 2015}} {{Infobox television | show_name = European Closing Bell | image = | caption = Logo from 9 March 2015 | genre = [[business]] [[news program]] | creator = | director = | developer = | presenter = [[Louisa Bojesen]] (2010-2015)
[[Ross Westgate]] (2003-2004, 2011-2012)
[[Guy Johnson (journalist)|Guy Johnson]] (2007-2011)
[[Simon Hobbs]] (2003-2007)
[[Kavita Maharaj]] (2003-2004) | voices = | narrated = | theme_music_composer = | opentheme = | endtheme = | composer = | country = United Kingdom | language = | num_seasons = | num_episodes = | list_episodes = | executive_producer = | producer = | asst_producer = | editor = | location = | camera = | runtime = 60 [[minute]]s | network = [[CNBC Europe]] | picture_format = | audio_format = | first_run = | first_aired = 2003-06-02{{Cite news | last = Ellery | first = Simon | title = MEDIA: CNBC revamps schedule | publisher = [[PR Week]] | date = 2003-05-30 | url = http://www.prweek.com/uk/search/article/181382// | accessdate = 2007-07-23}} | last_aired = 2015-12-18 | preceded_by = '''''[[European Market Wrap]]''''' | followed_by = '''''[[Squawk Alley]]''''' | related = | website = https://www.cnbc.com/id/15838629/site/14081545/ }} '''''European Closing Bell''''' (prior to June 2003 known as '''''European Market Wrap''''' ) was a [[television programme]] aired on [[business]] [[news]] [[television station|channel]] [[CNBC Europe]] from 5pm to 6pm [[Central European Time|CET]] (4pm to 5pm [[Western European Time|WET]]), and from 11am to 12pm on [[CNBC World]] in the United States. The programme was presented from [[London]] by [[Louisa Bojesen]]. The show covered the last half-hour of [[Trader (finance)|trades]] in the European [[stock market|equity markets]], and reported on the day's final numbers and top stories as the markets close at 5:30pm CET. As the major European markets are electronic, no actual "closing bell" was rung - nonetheless there was a countdown on the CNBC Europe [[Digital on-screen graphic|strap]] and video wall until the close of trade. Other regular segments included a daily "Guest Investor" and a [[technical analysis]] slot. Prior to 26 March 2007, the programme ran for two hours until 7pm CET. The second hour of the programme was of a slower pace, offering a more in-depth look at financial and political events. During major European [[trade fair]]s and political events such as [[European Union|EU]] summits and [[election]]s, ''European Closing Bell'' was often anchored live from these events. Many of these features were incorporated into the extended ''[[Europe Tonight]]'' after its relaunch on the same date. The theme music for the programme is the same as that used by the US version of ''[[Closing Bell]]''. On 9 March 2015, ''European Closing Bell'' launched new titles based on the US version used since 13 October 2014. On 18 December 2015, ''European Closing Bell'' ended its 12-year run as it was replaced with the US-produced ''[[Squawk Alley]]'', which began airing on CNBC Europe on 21 December 2015. ==See also== *''[[Europe Tonight]]'' (discontinued at the end of 2009) *''[[Closing Bell]]'' ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== #[https://www.cnbc.com/id/15838629/site/14081545/ ''European Closing Bell'' - CNBC.com] #{{IMDb title|2272081}} {{CNBC World Business Day}} {{CNBC Europe Business Day}} [[Category:CNBC World programs]] [[Category:CNBC Europe programmes]] [[Category:British television news programmes]] [[Category:2003 British television programme debuts]] [[Category:2000s British television series]] [[Category:Business-related television series]] [[Category:2010s British television series]] [[Category:2015 British television programme endings]]

{{One source|date=September 2009}} {{infobox Organization |name = European Council for Business Education |image = |image_border = |size = |caption = |map = |msize = |mcaption = |abbreviation = ECBE |motto = |formation = 1995 <ref name=handbook>{{cite journal |title=European Council for Business Education|url=http://www.universitieshandbook.com/directory/canton-vaud/european-council-for-business-education|journal=http://www.universitieshandbook.com}}</ref> |extinction = |type = NGO |status = |purpose = [[educational accreditation]] |headquarters = |location = [[Brussels, Belgium|Brussels]] |region_served = |membership = |language = |leader_title = President |leader_name = Martin Janku<ref>[http://www.ecbe.eu/index.php?id=11 ECBE.eu - Organisation]</ref> |main_organ = |parent_organization = |affiliations = |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = [http://www.ecbe.eu www.ecbe.eu] |remarks = }} The '''European Council for Business Education''' (ECBE) was founded in 1991<ref name=handbook/> as an independent, not-for-profit organisation<ref>{{cite journal |title=European Council of Business Education|url=http://www.smcuniversity.com/Accreditation/european-council-of-business-education.html|journal=http://www.smcuniversity.com}}</ref> headquartered in [[Belgium]].<ref>{{cite journal |title=Link Group European Council for Business Education|url=http://www.link-group.eu/content/european-council-business-education-ecbe|journal=http://www.link-group.eu}}</ref> The aim of ECBE is to accredit [[business school|schools of business]] from across Europe to ensure excellence in business education and teaching. ECBE's [[educational accreditation|accreditation]] process is based upon self and peer evaluation, aimed to ensure the continual improvement of educational quality. ECBE is overseen by a Board of Directors elected from the accredited members. A separate Board of Commissioners, independent of the Board of Directors are selected to oversee the application of procedures and the awarding of accreditation. ECBE is a registered affiliate of the [[European Association for Quality Assurance in Higher Education]] (ENQA).<ref>{{cite journal |title=AFFILIATES ENQA|url=http://www.enqa.eu/index.php/enqa-agencies/affiliates/|journal=http://www.enqa.eu}}</ref> and [[Council for Higher Education Accreditation]] (CHEA) International Quality Group (IQG) [https://web.archive.org/web/20141003190226/http://www.cheainternational.org/pdf/CIQG%20Members.pdf]

revision.text:
{{medical citations needed|date=September 2018}} '''Experience-focused counselling''' ('''EFC''') is an approach to [[counselling]] aimed specifically at those who experience [[Auditory hallucination|auditory hallucinations]], [[Visual hallucination|visions]] or other phenomena which are commonly associated with [[schizophrenia]] and other mental disorders.
== History ==
The term "experience-focused counseling" originated from traditional talk therapy,<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://dsm.psychiatryonline.org/doi/book/10.1176/appi.books.9780890425596|title=Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders|last=American Psychiatric Association|date=2013-05-22|publisher=American Psychiatric Association|isbn=0890425558|language=en|doi=10.1176/appi.books.9780890425596}}</ref>{{better source|date=September 2018}} which focuses on discussing the experiences of the individual to examine the cause of their symptoms. This type of therapy is most common in trauma survivors.{{cn|date=September 2018}} Experience-focused counseling is used or referred to in the long-term treatment of trauma and mental health conditions and is focused on the traumatic experiences and symptoms of the person receiving the treatment to work through them and slowly move towards recovery.
Experience-focused counseling is now a new sub-type of counseling which has become the foundation of the peer movement,{{clarify|date=September 2018}} and is often used in [[peer support]].{{cn|date=September 2018}}
== Providers == Counselors,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.counseling.org/|title=American Counseling Association {{!}}A professional home for counselors|website=www.counseling.org|access-date=2018-07-30}}</ref> mentors, psychologists,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bls.gov/ooh/life-physical-and-social-science/psychologists.htm|title=Psychologists: Occupational Outlook Handbook:: U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics|website=www.bls.gov|language=en-us|access-date=2018-07-30}}</ref> psychiatrists, and social workers<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bls.gov/ooh/community-and-social-service/social-workers.htm|title=Social Workers: Occupational Outlook Handbook:: U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics|website=www.bls.gov|language=en-us|access-date=2018-07-30}}</ref> all provide different levels of experience-focused counseling depending on the training they have received and their scope of practice. Many use traditional talk therapy<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.psychologytoday.com/us/blog/the-couch/201011/does-talk-therapy-really-work|title=Does Talk Therapy Really Work?|website=Psychology Today|language=en-US|access-date=2018-07-30}}</ref> methods which were the original foundation of the experience-focused counseling movement.
In addition to individual practitioners, many agencies and nonprofits have also began to provide peer supportive services, such as the National Alliance on Mental Illness (NAMI),<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nami.org/|title=NAMI|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> the National Peer support Network,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://peersforprogress.org/npscln/|title=National Peer Support Network {{!}} Peers For Progress|website=peersforprogress.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-07-30}}</ref> the National Peer Helpers Association,<ref name="tigweb peer">{{Cite web|url=https://orgs.tigweb.org/national-peer-helpers-association-npha|title=National Peer Helpers Associat... - Organizations - TakingITGlobal|website=orgs.tigweb.org|language=en|access-date=2018-07-30}}</ref> SAMHSA,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.samhsa.gov/|title=SAMHSA - Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration|website=www.samhsa.gov|language=en|access-date=2018-07-30}}</ref> National Peer Review Committee,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.aicpa.org/interestareas/peerreview/community/nationalprc.html|title=National Peer Review Committee (NPRC)|website=AICPA|language=en|access-date=2018-07-30}}</ref> and numerous independent service providers and community mental healthcare providers. Now, each state in the U.S. has incorporated this type of experience-focused counseling into their mental healthcare practices.
== Method == Depending on the symptoms, histories and traumas of the individual receiving treatment, the methods of treatment may vary, as the experience-focused counseling and peer support movement<ref name="tigweb peer"/> focuses on the worldview of the individuals. Typically, experience-focused counseling is performed by discussing the symptoms of the individual and their emotional and physical responses to trauma and/or mental illness by examining the individuals' current and past experiences to locate the cause(s) of their symptoms.
By focusing on the experience of the individual rather than the illness, the provider can begin to assist their client in finding the root cause of the trauma and onset of the symptoms causing the distress.
Various therapeutic techniques are used to assist the client in gaining insight and working through symptoms and emotional responses to their individual experiences. These may include:
* Standard talk therapies<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nimh.nih.gov/health/topics/psychotherapies/index.shtml|title=NIMH » Psychotherapies|website=www.nimh.nih.gov|language=en|access-date=2018-07-30}}</ref> * Cognitive behavioral therapy * EMDR<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://emdria.site-ym.com/page/emdr_therapy|title=EMDR Therapy - EMDR International Association|website=emdria.site-ym.com|access-date=2018-07-30}}</ref> * Cognitive processing therapy<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ptsd.va.gov/public/treatment/therapy-med/cognitive_processing_therapy.asp|title=Cognitive Processing Therapy for PTSD - PTSD: National Center for PTSD|website=www.ptsd.va.gov|language=en|access-date=2018-07-30}}</ref> * [[Art therapy]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://arttherapy.org/|title=American Art Therapy Association|website=American Art Therapy Association|language=en-US|access-date=2018-07-30}}</ref> * Nature therapy<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://nature-therapy.us/index.html|title=Nature Therapy|website=Nature Therapy|language=en|access-date=2018-07-30}}</ref> * Music therapy<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.musictherapy.org/|title=American Music Therapy Association {{!}} American Music Therapy Association (AMTA)|website=www.musictherapy.org|language=en|access-date=2018-07-30}}</ref> * Peer support<ref name="tigweb peer"/> * Group therapy
== Recipients == While many individuals with other forms of mental illnesses often benefit from a combination of therapies including experience-focused counseling,{{mcn|date=September 2018}} it is of note that peer support<ref name="mha peer">{{Cite news|url=http://www.mentalhealthamerica.net/center-peer-support|title=Center for Peer Support|date=2016-05-27|work=Mental Health America|access-date=2018-07-30|language=en}}</ref> is provided to every individual seeking help, regardless of diagnosis.{{cn|date=September 2018}}
Due to the fact that each person is unique in their traumas and experiences, people can and often do pursue other therapeutic interventions and treatments as well.
== Training and accreditations == Counselors, mentors, psychologists, psychiatrists, and social workers all provide different levels of experience-focused counseling depending on the type of therapy they choose to practice, the training they have received, and their scope of practice.
As multiple types of therapists have the ability to perform this type of counseling, the main providers of this technique are listed below:
* Board-certified art therapists (ATR)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.atcb.org/|title=ATCB - Art Therapy Credentials Board|last=ATCB|website=www.atcb.org|language=en|access-date=2018-07-30}}</ref> * Peer wellness specialists (PWS)<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.oregon.gov/oha/OEI/Pages/THW%20Peer-Wellness-Specialist-(PWS).aspx|title=Oregon Health Authority : Peer Wellness Specialist (PWS) : Office of Equity and Inclusion : State of Oregon|website=www.oregon.gov|language=en-us|access-date=2018-07-30}}</ref> * Peer support specialists (PSS)<ref name="mha peer"/><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.socialpsychology.org/endorsements/apadiv1.htm|title=From the Society for General Psychology|website=www.socialpsychology.org|access-date=2018-07-30}}</ref> * Eye movement desensitization and reprocessing (EMDR) specialists<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.emdr.com/what-is-emdr/|title=What is EMDR? {{!}} EMDR Institute – EYE MOVEMENT DESENSITIZATION AND REPROCESSING THERAPY|website=www.emdr.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-07-30}}</ref> * Brain spotting (BSP) specialists<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://brainspotting.com/|title=Brainspotting - Where you look affects how you feel|website=brainspotting.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-07-30}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|last=PESImentalhealth|title=Brainspotting with David Grand, Ph.D.|date=2016-10-26|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ma0Vu9BflhI|access-date=2018-07-30}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Trauma model of mental disorders]]
==References== <references />
<!-- (Commenting these out because they no longer seem to have much to do with the current content of the page, and because we don't generally collect lists of external links .If someone can use these to improve the article, that would be great.) * [https://archive.is/20121206012006/http://www.hearing-voices.com/ Official Dutch Hearing Voices Website: Mainly in Dutch language] * [http://www.intervoiceonline.org/ INTERVOICE Website: International Network for Training, Education and Research into Hearing Voices] * [http://www.mind.org.uk/Information/Booklets/Other/The+voice+inside.htm?wbc_purpose=Basic "The voice inside: A practical guide to coping with hearing voices"] -->
[[Category:Schizophrenia]] [[Category:Disability rights]] [[Category:Counseling]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2015}} {{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Musicians --> | name = Francis Buchholz | image = Francis Buchholz - MSG - 2.jpg | caption = Francis Buchholz with Michael Schenker"s Temple Of Rock at Kavarna Rock Fest 2012. | image_size = | background = non_vocal_instrumentalist | birth_name = | alias = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1954|2|19}} |birth_place = [[Hannover]], Germany | origin = | instrument = Bass | genre = [[Hard rock]], [[heavy metal music|Heavy metal]] | occupation = Musician | years_active = 1969–present | label = | associated_acts = [[Scorpions (band)|Scorpions]], Dawn Road, Dreamtide, Uli Jon Roth Sky Band, Michael Schenker's Temple Of Rock, Phantom V | website = }}
'''Francis Buchholz''' (born 19 February 1954 in [[Hannover]], Germany) is a German bass guitarist best known as a former member of the rock/hard rock band [[Scorpions (band)|Scorpions]].
==Biography== Buchholz discovered rock music at the age of 11. His first public appearance as a bass player was at age 15 while in a high school. From then on he played in different rock, blues and jazz bands in his hometown of Hannover. While a mechanical engineering student at the [[University of Hannover]] and taking classes at the [[Hochschule für Musik, Theater und Medien Hannover]], Buchholz joined Dawn Road, whose lineup included guitarist [[Ulrich Roth|Uli Roth]]. Eventually the musicians from Dawn Road and the Scorpions merged into a new incarnation of the Scorpions in 1973, with Buchholz on bass. Buchholz' first recording with the Scorpions was 1974's ''[[Fly to the Rainbow]]'', and he stayed as a band member for 18 years, recording 12 albums during the band's most commercially successful period. Together they sold over 15 million records in the USA alone and over 100 million records worldwide. For his success with the Scorpions, Buchholz was awarded with over 50 gold and platinum awards for record sales all over the world. He left the band after a disagreement over band management in 1992.<ref name="getready">{{cite web | url = http://www.getreadytoroll.com/interviews/francisbuchholz.htm | title = Francis Buchholz Interview | publisher = ''Get Ready To Roll'' | date = 5 September 2008}}</ref> His last album with the Scorpions was ''[[Crazy World (Scorpions album)|Crazy World]]'', which also contained the only Scorpions track Buchholz contributed to writing, "Kicks After Six".
Buchholz reunited with Uli Roth for a tour of Europe and the United States in 2005 and 2006. In 2008 Buchholz worked with the band Dreamtide as their bassplayer and co-producer, the album "Dream And Deliver" was released in Japan (King Records), Europe (AOR Heaven) and worldwide on iTunes.<ref name="dreamtidesite">{{cite web | url = http://dream-and-deliver.com | title = Band | publisher = Dreamtide Official | accessdate = 2009-05-22 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090512195613/http://dream-and-deliver.com/ | archivedate = 12 May 2009 | df = dmy-all }}</ref>
In 2012, Buchholz toured with former Scorpions lead guitarist [[Michael Schenker]] for the European dates of his "Temple of Rock - Lovedrive Reunion Tour" alongside former Scorpions drummer [[Herman Rarebell]], with ex-[[Rainbow (English band)|Rainbow]] vocalist [[Doogie White]] and MSG's Wayne Findley on guitars and keys. The "Temple of Rock – Lovedrive Reunion" tour went through Europe and Far East. A DVD, Blu-ray and Double-CD "Temple Of Rock - Live in Europe" was released for Christmas 2012.
Temple Of Rock's next album "Bridge The Gap" featured Buchholz on Bass, it was released in November 2013. A European tour in 2013 was followed by concerts in Mexico and South America and in 2014 they toured Japan and Europe. Their new album "Spirit On A Mission was released in 2015 and the band toured USA, Japan and Europe. Early in 2016 they play more shows in UK and Scandinavia.
==Equipment==
*Instruments: **[[Warwick (company)|Warwick]] Streamer Stage 1 Basses **[[Fender Precision Bass]]es, vintage from the Sixties **Ovation Legend Guitars *Equipment: **[[Ampeg SVT]] Amplifiers and 8x10 Cabinets **Custom Built 4x12'' Gauss Cabinets **Custom Built 2x15'' Electro Voice Cabinets **Custom Built JBL High Range Horn Cabinets **[[RotoSound]] strings **[[Dunlop Manufacturing|Jim Dunlop]] Nylon Picks **[[Shure]] Microphones **[[ProTools]] Recording System **Line6 Wireless system
==Personal life== In 1978, Buchholz founded a [[Public address|PA]] and [[stage lighting]] rental company, Rocksound, in Germany.<ref name="getready"/> The company began as a way to distribute special [[Horn loudspeaker|exponential loudspeaker cabinets]] Buchholz had developed, but also to provide employment for the Scorpions' [[Road crew|roadies]] when not on tour.<ref name="getready"/><ref name="hardrock">{{cite web | url = http://www.hardrock80.com/PAGEinterview/FRANCIS_BUCHHOLZ_02_2006_eng.htm | title = Interview: Francis Buchholz | publisher = hardrock80.com | last = Gegers | date = February 2006}}</ref> The company thrived in the 1980s and 1990s.
Buchholz lives in Hannover, Germany, with his wife Hella, they have a son and twin daughters.<ref name="hardrock"/>
In 1996, Buchholz authored the book ''Bass Magic'', he also worked as a record producer and [[Media consultant|consultant]].<ref name="hardrock"/>

{{multiple issues| {{POV|date=March 2018}} {{essay-like|date=March 2018}} {{more citations needed|date=March 2018}} }} '''Good Epidemiological Practices''' or '''Good Epidemiology Practices''' ('''GEP''') was a set of guidelines produced by the U.S. [[Chemical Manufacturers Association]] (CMA) in 1991 to improve [[epidemiology|epidemiologic]] research practices.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Guidelines for Good Epidemiology Practices for Occupational and Environmental Epidemiologic Research. The Chemical Manufacturers Association's Epidemiology Task Group. |journal=J Occup Med. |date=December 1991 |volume=33|issue=12|pages=1221–9|pmid= 1800677}}</ref> It was then adopted by the [[tobacco industry]] around 1993 as part of its "sound science" program to counter criticisms of the industry on health and environmental issues such as [[Passive smoking|secondhand smoke]].<ref name="ong">{{cite journal |title=Constructing "Sound Science" and "Good Epidemiology": Tobacco, Lawyers, and Public Relations Firms |journal=Am J Public Health|date=November 2001 |volume=91|issue=11|pages=1749–57|pmid=11684593 |pmc=1446868 |authors= Ong EK, Glantz SA}}</ref> It failed to make much impact on the US and European regulators, but may have had more influence in its later manifestations in Asia and particularly China.
The complexities of creating Good Epidemiological Practices developments have been examined by University of San Francisco researchers [[Stanton Glantz]] and [[Elisa K. Ong]] in papers such as "Tobacco Industry Efforts to Subvert the IARC's Second hand smoke study" published in ''[[The Lancet]]''.<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140-6736(00)02098-5/fulltext |journal=Lancet |date=8 April 2000 |volume=355|issue=9211|pages=1253–9|title=Tobacco industry efforts subverting International Agency for Research on Cancer's second-hand smoke study|authors=Ong EK, Glantz SA |pmid=10770318 |doi= 10.1016/S0140-6736(00)02098-5}}</ref> They argued that these were industry programs designed to manipulate the scientific standards of proof, and an attempt to set risk-evaluation standards that could be forced through by legislation, and imposed on the agencies ([[EPA]], [[Occupational Safety and Health Administration|OSHA]], etc.) to hamstring the agencies' ability to regulate.<ref name="ong"/>
==Tobacco's GEP== In February 1993, an executive of [[Philip Morris USA]], Ellen Merlo, wrote a memo to her CEO William Campbell outlining their strategies to discredit the 1992 report by the [[US Environmental Protection Agency]] (EPA) that identified secondhand smoke as a [[List of IARC Group 1 carcinogens|Group A human carcinogen]], and to counter what she described as "[[junk science]]".<ref name="ong"/> Their public relations firm, APCO Associates, launched a "sound science" coalition in the United States, and [[The Advancement of Sound Science Coalition]] (TASSC) was formed three months later in May 1993, with [[Garrey Carruthers]] the chairman.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2006/sep/19/ethicalliving.g2 |title=The denial industry |first=George |last=Monbiot |date=September 19, 2006 |work=The Guardian }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZvIZAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA139&lpg=PA139#v=onepage&q&f=false |title= Our Daily Poison: From Pesticides to Packaging, How Chemicals Have Contaminated the Food Chain and Are Making Us Sick|first=Marie-Monique |last=Robin |pages=138–140 |publisher=The New Press |date=9 December 2014 |isbn=9781595589309 }}</ref> [[George L. Carlo]], a science entrepreneur who worked with [[Federal Focus]] Inc., prepared one of the early draft documents.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.industrydocumentslibrary.ucsf.edu/tobacco/docs/qgjm0128|title=Industry Documents Library|website=www.industrydocumentslibrary.ucsf.edu |date=May 31, 1994}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.industrydocumentslibrary.ucsf.edu/tobacco/docs/lxjm0128|title=Industry Documents Library|website=www.industrydocumentslibrary.ucsf.edu |date=June 15, 1994}}</ref>
At this time the legislative{{which|date=March 2018}} and public activist{{who|date=March 2018}} attacks on the tobacco industry had escalated, and they{{who|date=March 2018}} blamed this on the "twisted science" used by the EPA.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://industrydocuments.library.ucsf.edu/tobacco/docs/qpfx0005|title=Statements by EPA|website=industrydocuments.library.ucsf.edu}}</ref> In Europe the UN's [[International Agency for Research on Cancer]] (IARC) was about to release a similar report, which the tobacco industry also needed to counter.
Helmut Reif, [[Thomas Borelli|Tom Borelli]] and Mitch Ritter at Philip Morris's Science & Technology division thought the CMA's GEP could be improved to help PM develop standards for secondhand smoke epidemiological studies. This initiative to "constructively improve" epidemiology would enlist the assistance of the industry's consultants, and they could then run an "offensive strategy"—essentially another proactive effort by the industry to shape the scientific process.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://industrydocuments.library.ucsf.edu/tobacco/docs/frbb0120|title=Industry Documents Library|website=industrydocuments.library.ucsf.edu|date=March 17, 1994}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.industrydocumentslibrary.ucsf.edu/tobacco/docs/pmgx0111|title=Industry Documents Library|website=www.industrydocumentslibrary.ucsf.edu|date=March 31, 1994}}</ref>
Joanna Sullivan, Philip Morris's main PR in Europe, advised her American superiors{{who|date=March 2018}} (June 1994) on how GEP might be used to combat the IARC's report, since this would give United Nations weight to the claim that second-hand smoke was potentially cancerous to non-smokers. By establishing the standards of epidemiology and by using their influence in Congress to have GEP mandated by legislation, they hoped to design a set of established procedural standards for epidemiology.
The innovation here, was that they{{who|date=March 2018}} aimed to attack the techniques relied on by the EPA and IARC scientists. In the past, they{{who|date=March 2018}} had focussed attacks on specific adverse scientific findings and reports. GEP was designed to directed an attack on the techniques of epidemiology itself.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.industrydocumentslibrary.ucsf.edu/tobacco/docs/gzwb0003|title=Industry Documents Library|website=www.industrydocumentslibrary.ucsf.edu|date=June 6, 1994}}</ref>
They{{who|date=March 2018}} may have had little hope that this would be widely accepted by the majority of epidemiologists or by the regulators{{which|date=March 2018}}, but it made possible a vigorous public relations campaign in the media to challenge and denigrate any adverse findings.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://industrydocuments.library.ucsf.edu/tobacco/docs/qnmj0115|title=Industry Documents Library|website=industrydocuments.library.ucsf.edu|date=June 16, 1994}}</ref>
===Panels and Conferences=== Initially Philip Morris utilised a small panel of trusted epidemiologists{{who|date=March 2018}} who regularly serviced the industry when it needed to defend against some adverse finding.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.industrydocumentslibrary.ucsf.edu/tobacco/docs/jgjm0052|title=Industry Documents Library|website=www.industrydocumentslibrary.ucsf.edu|date=August 1, 1991}}</ref> They were requested to improve on the Chemical Manufacturer's Association's GEP. Later they extended this mandate by conducting seminars on GEP and good risk-assessment practice around the world{{where|date=March 2018}}. The tobacco industry itself needed to remain invisible and so they needed the front provided by third-party think-tanks and old allies.
The main organisation hired to run the GEP program was [[Federal Focus]] Inc., a PR company set up during the second term of the [[Reagan Administration]] by two top Agency officials, [[Thorne Auchter]], who had been the Director of the OSHA (Occupational Safety & Health Administration) and [[James J. Tozzi]] who had been Reagan's "Deregulation Czar" as head of the OIRA (Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs), at the OMB (Office of Management & Budget). These two and the head of the EPA ([[Anne Gorsuch Burford]]) were among the 20 or so top Agency executives forced (or encouraged) to resign over Reagan's regulatory scandals.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.industrydocumentslibrary.ucsf.edu/tobacco/docs/kmvv0175|title=Industry Documents Library|website=www.industrydocumentslibrary.ucsf.edu|date=December 28, 1994}}</ref>
Jim Tozzi's technique at the OIRA was to block regulators{{which|date=March 2018}} from regulating by denying their agencies funding unless they cancelled one regulation before adding another. (Tozzi and Auchter also ran [[Multinational Business Services]], and the [[Institute for Regulatory Policy]]).
The main tobacco law firm, Covington & Burling (C&B) was also involved both in promoting the idea and in recruiting scientists{{who|date=March 2018}} willing to participate, usually only when assured that payment would be laundered through the law firm. C&B lawyer [[John Rupp]] initiated similar activities in Italy and Germany. The total expenses for this program in 1997 were about $300,000.
The GEP program "experts" that Auchter and Tozzi enlisted were pre-screened by Philip Morris Issues Managers and Federal Focus, and the results they produced were pre-tested at a number of conferences (which often didn't carry the GEP name). The first, known as the Lansdowne Conference, was held at a US conference center with only a few of their most trusted scientist helpers. They then widened the advisory pool and held a [[London Conference]] where Philip Morris opened the operation to British-American Tobacco and the other companies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.industrydocumentslibrary.ucsf.edu/tobacco/docs/hlvc0056|title=Industry Documents Library: Appendix Table A-5|website=www.industrydocumentslibrary.ucsf.edu}}</ref> They established what became known as the London Principles.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.industrydocumentslibrary.ucsf.edu/tobacco/docs/hhdy0090|title=Principles for Evaluating Epidemiologic Data in Regulatory Risk Assessment|website=www.industrydocumentslibrary.ucsf.edu}}</ref> A German conference soon followed.
Generally GEP failed to influence policy makers in America and Europe{{where|date=March 2018}}, so it was tried in Asia through conferences of the Asian [[WhiteCoats]] group (collectively known as 'ARTIST') and with other recruits in Kuala Lumpur, Hong-Kong, Yokohama, Beijing, and then Guangzhou.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.industrydocumentslibrary.ucsf.edu/tobacco/docs/hjhh0049|title=International Workshop on Risk Assessment and Good Epidemiological Practices|website=www.industrydocumentslibrary.ucsf.edu}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://industrydocuments.library.ucsf.edu/tobacco/docs/qjjv0123|title=Quality Assurance on in Epidemology |author=Robert Walk|website=industrydocuments.library.ucsf.edu |date=January 6, 1997 }}</ref>
===The inadvertent whistleblower=== Ted Sanders, who ran the Scientific Affairs operations for Philip Morris in Europe, provides us{{who|date=March 2018}} with an excellent overview of how the Philip Morris GEP unravelled in a long letter of complaint to Cathy Ellis, his executive overseer in Brussels (Apr 3 1998).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.industrydocumentslibrary.ucsf.edu/tobacco/docs/ggdh0180|title=Industry Documents Library|website=www.industrydocumentslibrary.ucsf.edu}}</ref>

revision.text:
{{more citations needed|date=March 2013}} {{Infobox company | name = Hearst Television, Inc. | logo = Hearst logo.svg | caption = television inc | former_name = Hearst Broadcasting (1931-1997)
Hearst-Argyle Television (1997-2009) | type = [[Subsidiary]] | industry = [[Terrestrial television|Broadcast Television]]
[[Production company|Television Production]] | predecessor = Hearst Broadcasting
Argyle Television Holdings II | area_served = [[United States]] (Nationwide) | key_people = Jordan Wertlieb
([[President (corporate title)|President]]) | products = [[Broadcast television]] | revenue = {{profit}} [[United States dollar|US$]] 785.4 million (2006) | operating_income = {{profit}} [[United States dollar|US$]] 228.8 million (2006) | net_income = {{profit}} [[United States dollar|US$]] 98.7 million (2006) | num_employees = approx. 3000 (full-time) | parent = [[Hearst Communications]] | subsid = [[Litton Entertainment]] | footnotes = | foundation = {{Start date and age|1997}}, by a merger of Hearst Broadcasting and Argyle Television Holdings II | location = [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], United States | homepage = {{Official website|http://www.hearst.com/broadcasting}} }} '''Hearst Television, Inc.''' (formerly '''Hearst-Argyle Television''') is a broadcasting company in the [[United States]] owned by [[Hearst Communications]]. From 1998 to mid-2009, the company traded its common stock on the [[New York Stock Exchange]] under the symbol "HTV." Hearst-Argyle was formed in 1997 with the merger of Hearst Corporation's broadcasting division and stations owned by '''Argyle Television Holdings II''',[http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-19263839.html Rathbun, Elizabeth A. "Hearst stocks up on Argyles; merged TV group with 14 stations, 11.6% coverage is valued at $1.8 billion.], ''[[Broadcasting & Cable]]''. March 31, 1997. [[HighBeam Research]]. (February 17, 2011). which is partially related to the company of the same name who (in 1994) sold its stations to [[New World Communications]], stations that eventually became [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]]-owned stations (Hearst itself, unusual for any American broadcast group, has never held a Fox affiliation on any of their stations). Hearst's involvement in broadcasting dates to the 1920s. In terms of audience reach, Hearst is the third-largest group owner of [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]-affiliated stations, behind the [[E. W. Scripps Company]] and [[Sinclair Broadcast Group]], and ahead of [[Tegna, Inc.]], and the second-largest group owner of [[NBC]] affiliates, behind Tegna. Hearst-owned ABC affiliates in [[National Football League]] markets simulcast ''[[Monday Night Football]]'' games from [[ESPN]] that involve these teams - ESPN is 20% owned by Hearst, the rest being owned by ABC's parent, [[The Walt Disney Company]]. Other Hearst-owned stations also carry ESPN-aired NFL games, even though they are affiliated with other networks (like [[WBAL-TV]], Baltimore's NBC affiliate). Hearst also holds some [[joint venture]]s for [[broadcast syndication|syndicated programming]] with [[NBCUniversal Television Distribution]]. On June 3, 2009, the Hearst Corporation announced that it would purchase substantially all of the stock not held by Hearst. Hearst-Argyle Television then dropped "Argyle" from its name and became a wholly owned subsidiary of the Hearst Corporation.[http://www.broadcastingcable.com/article/277983-Hearst_Moves_On_Merger.php Hearst Moves On Merger], ''[[Broadcasting & Cable]]'', June 3, 2009 ==Digital television== In February 2009, Hearst-Argyle announced that its stations (except for [[KITV]] and its satellites in [[Hawaii]], which had already completed their transition to digital, and [[WPTZ]] in [[Plattsburgh, New York]] and [[WNNE]] in [[Hartford, Vermont]], which followed the other [[Champlain Valley]] in transitioning on February 17, 2009) would comply with the new DTV transition date of June 12, 2009. ==Hearst-owned stations== [[File:Hearst-Argyle Television logo.png|right|thumb|Hearst-Argyle Television logo, 2007-2009]] Currently, Hearst owns a total of 34 overall television stations but considers two groups of four stations and an NBC station with an ABC [[digital subchannel]] joint operations, bringing their count down to 31 under that consideration: eleven NBC affiliates, fifteen ABC affiliates (one as a subchannel of an NBC affiliate, and one which acts as a two-station simulcast), two [[CBS]] affiliates, six [[The CW|CW]] affiliates (two traditional, two subchannel (which are part of a two-station simulcast), and two channel shares), two [[MyNetworkTV]] affiliates (one traditional, one subchannel), and one [[Independent station (North America)|independent station]]. Most of the company's subchannel stations broadcast either [[Weigel Broadcasting]]'s [[MeTV]] or NBC's [[Cozi TV]] through national affiliation deals, along with being charter carriers of Weigel's two newest concepts, [[Heroes & Icons]] and [[Movies!]]. Since December 1, 2014, [[Des Moines, Iowa|Des Moines]] CBS affiliate [[KCCI]] has used their third subchannel as an H&I affiliate carrying MyNetworkTV programming in primetime. Hearst also owns two radio stations in [[Baltimore]], the last remaining from the company divesting most of their radio assets after the [[Telecommunications Act of 1996]] went into effect. As already mentioned above, none of Hearst's stations have ever held a [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] affiliation, with the exception of two WMUR translators in the northern part of New Hampshire dis-affiliating with the network upon Hearst's assumption of ownership of WMUR. [[File:Candy Altman at the 68th Annual Peabody Awards for Hearst-Argyle Television-Commitment 2008.jpg|thumb|Candy Altman at the 68th Annual [[Peabody Awards]] for Hearst-Argyle Television-Commitment 2008]] Some Hearst-owned stations use the "Commitment (Year)" banner for all political news coverage leading up to the local, national, and statewide elections in lieu of a localized version of their associated network's political branding. This started in 2000. Hearst also maintains a [[Washington, D.C.]] [[News bureau|bureau]] to assist their stations in coverage of national politics, including on-air reporters and facilities and equipment assistance for local stations. Many Hearst stations license the "Operation High School" branding for coverage of local [[high school sports]]. In 2007, Hearst-Argyle became one of the first television broadcasting groups to post their news stories on [[YouTube]]. [[WCVB]], [[KCRA-TV|KCRA]], [[WTAE-TV|WTAE]], [[WBAL-TV|WBAL]] and [[WMUR-TV|WMUR]] were the first stations in Hearst-Argyle's station group to do this. Until 2009, three of Hearst's television stations ([[KCWE]], [[WMOR-TV]], and [[WPBF]]) and its two radio stations ([[WBAL (AM)|WBAL radio]] and [[WIYY]]) were owned by Hearst Broadcasting, Inc., an indirect wholly owned subsidiary of the Hearst Corporation through which Hearst ultimately controlled Hearst-Argyle Television, as opposed to Hearst-Argyle itself; Hearst-Argyle still operated these stations under a management services agreement. These stations were transferred to Hearst Television shortly after its privatization.{{cite web|title=Explanation to FCC of Hearst-Argyle privatization|url=https://licensing.fcc.gov/cdbs/CDBS_Attachment/getattachment.jsp?appn=101312805&qnum=5010©num=1&exhcnum=1|format=PDF|date=May 18, 2009|work=CDBS Public Access|publisher=[[Federal Communications Commission]]|accessdate=August 31, 2012}}{{cite web|title=Explanation to FCC of Hearst reorganization|url=https://licensing.fcc.gov/cdbs/CDBS_Attachment/getattachment.jsp?appn=101324506&qnum=5010©num=1&exhcnum=1|format=PDF|date=July 29, 2009|work=CDBS Public Access|publisher=Federal Communications Commission|accessdate=August 31, 2012}} Hearst's television and radio cluster in Baltimore additionally serves as the [[flagship station]]s and operation bases for the [[Baltimore Ravens]] radio and television networks. On August 20, 2014, it was announced that Hearst Television would acquire [[WVTM]] in Birmingham, Alabama and [[WJCL (TV)|WJCL]] in Savannah, Georgia from [[Media General]], which divested those stations under FCC advisement as part of their acquisition of [[LIN Media]].{{cite news|title=Media General, LIN Sell Stations In 5 Markets|url=http://www.tvnewscheck.com/article/78615/media-general-lin-sell-stations-in-5-markets|accessdate=August 20, 2014|work=TVNewsCheck|date=August 20, 2014}}{{cite news|last1=Malone|first1=Michael|title=Media General, LIN Divest Stations in Five Markets|url=http://www.broadcastingcable.com/news/currency/media-general-lin-divest-stations-five-markets/133323|accessdate=August 20, 2014|work=[[Broadcasting & Cable]]|date=August 20, 2014}} On January 6, 2017, Hearst acquired majority control of [[Charleston, South Carolina]]-based [[broadcast syndication|syndicator]] [[Litton Entertainment]], which has control of four of the five [[E/I]]-compliant Saturday morning blocks on the five major broadcast networks, along with being a syndicator of traditional programming. The deal closed on February 1.{{cite news|url=https://variety.com/2017/tv/news/hearst-entertainment-litton-acquires-syndication-1201954104/|title=Hearst Acquires Majority Stake in Independent Distributor Litton Entertainment |last=Littleton|first=Cynthia|date=6 January 2017|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|accessdate=27 January 2017}} ===Television production=== Hearst Television also produces the weekly public-affairs program ''[[Matter of Fact with Soledad O'Brien]]'', which in fall 2018 entered its fourth season. Outside of the Hearst stations and [[A&E (TV network)|A&E]], the show is distributed in national [[broadcast syndication]] by [[Sony Pictures Television]]. ===Television stations=== Stations are listed alphabetically by state and [[city of license]]. '''Note:''' * ('''**''') – ''Indicates a station that was [[construction permit#broadcasting|built]] and [[broadcast license|signed-on]] by Hearst.'' * ('''§§''') – ''Indicates a station that was owned by Argyle Television Holdings II prior to the formation of Hearst-Argyle Television in 1997.'' * ('''~~''') - ''Indicates a station that was affected by an ownership swap between Argyle II and [[Gannett Company|Gannett]] in 1997.'' * ('''≈≈''') – ''Indicates a station that was affected by an ownership swap between Hearst-Argyle and [[Smith Media|Sunrise Television]] in 1998.'' * ('''¤¤''') – ''Indicates a station that was owned by [[Pulitzer, Inc.|Pulitzer]] prior to its acquisition by Hearst-Argyle in 1998.'' * ('''κ''') – ''Indicates a station that was owned by Kelly Broadcasting prior to its acquisition by Hearst-Argyle in 1999.'' * ('''^^''') - ''Indicates a station that was acquired by Hearst from [[Media General]] in 2014. {| class="toccolours" border="2" cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0" style="margin: 1em 1em 1em 0; background: #f9f9f9; border: 1px #aaa solid; border-collapse: collapse" |- style="vertical-align: top; text-align: center;" !style="background: #e3e3e3;"| [[City of license]] / [[Media market|Market]] !style="background: #e3e3e3;"| Station !style="background: #e3e3e3;"| Channel

'''InciWeb''' is an interagency all-[[risk]] incident [[Web information system|web information management system]] provided by the [[United States Forest Service]] released in 2004.<ref>[http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/http%3A%2F%2Finciweb.nwcg.gov]. [[Alexa Internet]].</ref> It was originally developed for [[wildfire|wildland fire]] emergencies, but can be also used for other [[emergency]] incidents ([[natural disaster]]s, such as [[earthquake]]s, [[flood]]s, [[hurricane]]s, and [[tornado]]es).<ref>[http://gacc.nifc.gov/admin/about_us/about_us.htm About Us], [[National Interagency Fire Center|National Geographic Area Coordination Center]]s (GACC).</ref>
==Introduction== [[Image:2015 Cajon Pass wildfire (North Fire).jpeg|300px|thumb|right| InciWeb photo of the 2015 [[North Fire]] in California]] It was developed with two primary missions:
* 1. Provide the public a single source of incident related information * 2. Provide a standardized reporting tool for the [[Public relations|Public Affairs]] community<ref>[http://inciweb.nwcg.gov/about/ About this Site]. InciWeb. Retrieved 2009-08-30.</ref>
Official announcements include evacuations, road closures, news releases, maps, photographs, and basic info and current situation about the incident.
Incident information can be accessed by: * web browser at http://inciweb.nwcg.gov * [[Twitter]]<ref>[https://twitter.com/inciweb inciweb on Twitter]</ref> * [[RSS]] web feed
==Technical == The original [[Application software|application]] was hosted at the [[United States Forest Service]] - Wildland Fire Training and Conference Center, at [[McClellan Airfield]], [[California]], comprising three [[Server (computing)|server]]s: *[[Database server]] *[[Application server|Administrative server]] *[[Load balancing (computing)|Load balancer]] for the public content which routes traffic to a pool of eight servers.
[[Web traffic]] averages 2 million plus [[Hit (internet)|hits]] daily during the fire season with the ability to handle 3.5 million hits.
The servers were moved to the National information Technology Center (NITC),<ref>[http://www.ocio.usda.gov/nitc/index.html Enterprise IT Solutions: About NITC]. Office of the Chief Information Officer, [[United States Department of Agriculture]].</ref> [[Kansas City, Missouri]] on July 16, 2008, along with the release of version 2.0;<ref>[http://www.myfirecommunity.net/Neighborhood.aspx?ID=385 Public home page for InciWeb]. MyFireCommunity.Net - Neighborhood. The professional collaboration site for wildland fire practitioners.</ref> the current version is 2.2.
==Availability issues== InciWeb was having technical difficulties due to the high volume of Internet users trying to access the site during the September–October 2006 [[Day Fire]] <ref>[http://www.emergencity.com/case-study.shtml Case Study], Emergencity.</ref> and the [[Summer 2008 California wildfires]].<ref>[http://westinstenv.org/firetrack/2008/06/28/inciweb-problems-are-bull/ InciWeb Problems Are Bull…]. June–July 2008. W.I.S.E. Fire Tracking, Western Institute for Study of the Environment. Retrieved 2009-09-02.</ref>
==Participating agencies== *[[United States Forest Service]] *[[Bureau of Land Management]] *[[Bureau of Indian Affairs]] *[[Fish and Wildlife Service]] *[[National Park Service]] *[[National Oceanic & Atmospheric Administration]] *[[Department of the Interior]] Office of Aircraft Services *[[National Association of State Foresters]] *[[United States Fire Administration]]
These same agencies are also in the [[National Interagency Fire Center]].
==See also== *[[Incident Command System]] *[[Incident management]]

Fire Information for Communities at Risk in Interface Wildfires: Lessons Learned From the 2003 Southern California Megafires. pages 135-152 in [http://www.fs.fed.us/psw/publications/documents/psw_gtr209/psw_gtr209.pdf Fire Social Science Research From the Pacific Southwest Research Station: Studies Supported by National Fire Plan Funds]. August 2008. [[United States Forest Service]]. InciWeb is mentioned on page 139, footnote 11.

'''João Carlos Di Genio''' is a [[Brazil]]ian [[physician]] and [[educator]]. He created and is the main owner of the largest educational holding in the country, comprised by the [[Sistema Objetivo]] (primary, secondary and preparatory schools) and the [[Universidade Paulista]] (UNIP), a private university with more than 60 campuses all over Brazil.
Di Genio started his educational career while he was a medical student at the [[University of São Paulo]], in [[São Paulo]] in the 1960s. The mandatory entrance examination to the [[medical school]]s was increasingly tougher and many high school students. The inborn entrepreneurial spirit of di Genio led him to create a one-year preparatory pre-med course, initially in his own home. The success achieved by the course prompted him to establish a formal school, together with three of his colleagues ([[Drauzio Varella]], Tadasi Ito and Roger Patti), which was named ''Curso Pré-Vestibular Nove de Julho''. This later became the Objetivo prep course. Other educational levels were subsequently added.
==External links== * [http://www.unip.br Universidade Paulista] * [http://www.objetivo.br Sistema Objetivo]
